articles.headline: In U.S., Expert Witnesses Are Partisan
articles.snippet: Unlike in American courts, in most of the rest of the world expert witnesses are selected by judges and are meant to be neutral.
articles.abstract: Unlike in American courts, in most of the rest of the world expert witnesses are selected by judges and are meant to be neutral.
articles.lead_paragraph: Judge Denver D. Dillard was trying to decide whether a slow-witted Iowa man accused of acting as a drug mule was competent to stand trial. But the conclusions of the two psychologists who gave expert testimony in the case, Judge Dillard said, were “polar opposites.”

articles.headline: Stocks Gain as Oil’s Fall Continues
articles.snippet: On Monday, oil traded below $113 a barrel, its lowest level since early May, and the euro, so strong for so long, tumbled below $1.49, its weakest level since February.
articles.abstract: On Monday, oil traded below $113 a barrel, its lowest level since early May, and the euro, so strong for so long, tumbled below $1.49, its weakest level since February.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oil prices fell again Monday, and the beaten-down dollar was bouncing back.

articles.headline: Cost-Cutting in New York, but a Boom in India
articles.snippet: Wall Street’s losses are fast becoming India’s gain, as jobs higher up the financial food chain are being exported to India and places less costly than New York and London.
articles.abstract: Wall Street’s losses are fast becoming India’s gain, as jobs higher up the financial food chain are being exported to India and places less costly than New York and London.
articles.lead_paragraph: GURGAON, India — On the top floor of a seven-story building in this dusty aspiring metropolis, Copal Partners churns out equity, fixed income and trading research for big name analysts and banks. It is a long way from the well-cooled corridors of Wall Street, and quarters are tight; business is up about 40 percent this year alone.

articles.headline: Leaving Wall Street for a Job Overseas
articles.snippet: As Wall Street’s troubles deepen, big investment banks are seizing the moment to ask high-value employees to move to financial hubs in Asia, Latin America and the Middle East.
articles.abstract: As Wall Street’s troubles deepen, big investment banks are seizing the moment to ask high-value employees to move to financial hubs in Asia, Latin America and the Middle East.
articles.lead_paragraph: Moving boxes have become a common sight at Wall Street firms, where tens of thousands of bankers and traders have been laid off as the credit squeeze drags on. But a few of the people packing up and saying goodbye are holding passports rather than pink slips. And some are being told to move abroad  or else.

articles.headline: Russia, and Putin, Assert Authority
articles.snippet: With a risky thrust into Georgia, Vladimir V. Putin has shown that he is still calling the shots in Russia.
articles.abstract: With a risky thrust into Georgia, Vladimir V. Putin has shown that he is still calling the shots in Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  Vladimir V. Putin, who came to office brooding over the wounds of a humiliated Russia, this week offered proof of its resurgence. So far, the West has been unable to check his thrust into Georgia. He is making decisions that could redraw the map of the Caucasus in Russia’s favor  or destroy relationships with Western powers that Russia once sought as strategic partners.

articles.headline: Russia Steps Up Its Push; West Faces Tough Choices
articles.snippet: The U.S. and its European allies seemed uncertain how to adjust to Russian actions in Georgia that could undermine democratic gains in the region.
articles.abstract: The U.S. and its European allies seemed uncertain how to adjust to Russian actions in Georgia that could undermine democratic gains in the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Russian troops stepped up their advance into Georgian territory on Monday, attempting to turn back the clock to the days when Moscow held uncontested sway over what it considers its “near abroad,” and arousing increasing alarm among Western leaders.

articles.headline: Analyzing Wall Street’s Research
articles.snippet: Since 2002, when research was formally separated from investment banking, the quality of research on Wall Street has deteriorated, and many top analysts have left the business.
articles.abstract: Since 2002, when research was formally separated from investment banking, the quality of research on Wall Street has deteriorated, and many top analysts have left the business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Frank P. Quattrone thinks Wall Street research has “proven to be a disaster, in my humble opinion.”

articles.headline: Global Trail of an Online Crime Ring
articles.snippet: Prosecutors say their own informant stole millions of credit card numbers in a case that reveals how the Internet is enabling new crimes on a vast scale.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors say their own informant stole millions of credit card numbers in a case that reveals how the Internet is enabling new crimes on a vast scale.
articles.lead_paragraph: As an international ring of thieves plundered the credit card numbers of millions of Americans, investigators struggled to figure out who was orchestrating the crimes in the United States.

articles.headline: Recall Leads Whole Foods to a Change
articles.snippet: Scrambling to contain fallout from a recall that threatens its reputation for quality, Whole Foods said it would tighten oversight of suppliers to keep unsafe products out of its stores.
articles.abstract: Scrambling to contain fallout from a recall that threatens its reputation for quality, Whole Foods said it would tighten oversight of suppliers to keep unsafe products out of its stores.
articles.lead_paragraph: Whole Foods Market said Monday it would tighten oversight of its suppliers to keep substandard products out of stores, after recalling ground beef that apparently sickened customers in two states.

articles.headline: Russia, in Accord With Georgians, Sets Withdrawal
articles.snippet: The Georgian and Russian presidents agreed early Wednesday to a framework that could end the war, but antagonisms still seethed.
articles.abstract: The Georgian and Russian presidents agreed early Wednesday to a framework that could end the war, but antagonisms still seethed.
articles.lead_paragraph: TBILISI, Georgia  The presidents of Georgia and Russia agreed early Wednesday morning on a framework that could end the war that flared up here five days ago, after Russia reasserted its traditional dominance of the region.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Ellen Barry

articles.headline: Sunnier Forecast for Corn and Soybean Harvest
articles.snippet: After an extremely worrisome start that fanned fears of famine and economic devastation, the nation’s most crucial crop is on track for a bountiful harvest, the government said Tuesday.
articles.abstract: After an extremely worrisome start that fanned fears of famine and economic devastation, the nation’s most crucial crop is on track for a bountiful harvest, the government said Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a worrisome start to the growing season that fanned fears of food shortages and huge economic losses, the nation’s most important crop is now on track for a bountiful harvest, the government said Tuesday.
